They reach you, each holding some piece of their past that somehow found them. Joana holds the telescope, and Sarah drags over the water purifier. Joshua's slung the guitar over his shoulder and Yusuf's still tinkering with his compass. (TEENEESE?) "What's going on, $name/Captain?" asks Yusuf. "What is all this?" Joshua scoffs. It's how you feel, without any solid sense of self to stand. With the fear of the unknown coming from past and future alike. But you can't give into that. Pulling up your right foot ever so slightly from the ground, you feel the suction of the boot latching on the best it can to the uneven sandy ground. How easy it would be to pull off and float away. "And we have a home we need to find a way back to." You loosen the pull on your foot, standing firmly on the ground. "So, what's next?" asks Yusuf. TASK: set up colony "Our primary goal is simple: find a way to survive here after our supplies have run out, thrive even." We must have landed on the night side of the planet." "So... there's no day and night?" asks Joshua. "Just, always day and always night?" "That is correct. "What's the hurry?" Again. It appears in front of you. Run: You move as fast as you can in the sand, in the suit, in the air like molasses, running running lunging to approach the figure. It appears further off each time you blink. The sun is higher in the sky, its warmth and radiation raining down on you, the cooling systems of the suit can only do so much. The figure simmers in the distance. The thought comes across your mind it could be a mirage, but you dispel that. It's real. Too much has happened for this to be imagination. You blink, and it's gone. Reappeared closer, to your right. You turn, making gains on the figure. Your breathing grows heavier, your heart rate faster. Several menacing beeps emit from your suit. "I recommend slowing down your pace, especially in this heat," says CINDI. "These suits were not designed for this kind of exertion in this environment." You continue, your steps turning into small jumps, heightened from the low gravity. After one of these, your foot catches the sand as you fall back, pushing your body softly into the sand. Last convoADD: Elliot gives Joshua sheet music Joshua (LN) couldn't stop adjusting the synthetic tablecloth draped over the cold metallic table, hoping some adjustment could bring the warmth he had imagined it to have in his mind. The low, yellow and orange lighting could trick someone into thinking a fire was burning nearby for a moment, but not much more. (choose / add music, mention wine / food) But the view could not be more brilliant. Joshua had plotted Enceladus' orbit so Saturn and its rings would sit just outside the window on this very evening. The rings streaked across the sky and the stars and the gas giant behind them as if there was some kind of splinter in the fabric of the universe, through this perfect gold shined through. Joshua knew it was just rock and ice, refracted light, but that almost made it all the more impossibly perfect. There's a harsh ring. "Your guest has arrived," says a deep voice, in a British accent. [[Turn to greet him.]] [[Keep looking at the window.]] "Let him in." You turn to see the doors shift apart, and Elliot (LAST NAME) walk through, oval spectacles and a thick woolen sweater. He looks around, at the table and tablecloth, the lighting, the view. And the music. "Let him in." You stare ahead at the cosmos before you as you hear the doors shift apart, and a pair of light footsteps approach you from behind. Elliot (LAST NAME) arrives at your left, wearing a thick woolen sweater, Saturn reflected in his oval spectacles. "Oh, this is lovely." His smile splinters across his face. [[I've got to use my perks for something.]] [[Not as lovely as you.]] "I've got to use my perks for something." Joshua pulls back one of the seats, by the window. Elliot looks down at it. His mouth opens, searching for words. "This is... it's all too much." "Not as lovely as you." Joshua pulls back one of the seats, by the window. "Please, don't say things like that." Elliot looks down at the seat. His mouth opens, searching for words. "This is... it's all too much." [[Just indulge me.]] [[I know you enjoy the extravagance.]] "Just indulge me. Please." The music is quiet in the background, filling the silences between words. "I'll try to enjoy myself. As a favor." Elliot takes the seat. "I know you enjoy the extravagance." The music is quiet in the background, filling the silences between words. "I can't hide anything from you, can I?" Elliot takes the seat. Joshua walks around to the other side of the small table and takes his own. Before each of them was a (figure out how food works describe here), and a long flask. "What's in the bottle?" asks Elliot. [[Red wine.]] [[A surprise.]] "A very special wine. Pinot noir, 2035. California. The storage unit has a small centrifuge that rotates the liquid, keeping it perfectly stable at Earth's gravity." Joshua connected the flask to the smaller glass container on Elliot's side of the table through a small tube. A dark emerald red liquid churns through. Elliot's eyes are wide. "I can't begin to imagine what this cost..." [[Then don't.]] [[Just taste it.]] "A surprise." Joshua connected the flask to the smaller glass container on Elliot's side of the table through a small tube. A dark emerald red liquid churns through. "That's not..." Elliot's eyes are wide. "I can't begin to imagine what this cost..." [[Then don't.]] [[Just taste it.]] "Then don't." "Just taste it." He pours himself a glass, the liquid floating inside the sealed container. Joshua raises his glass to Elliot, who slowly does the same. They both put their lips to the seal, opening the container allowing the liquid to be sucked in. Elliot's face is one of immediate revulsion, then a smile and laughter. "Oh, god. It's disgusting!" [[Sip it again.]] [[You don't like it?]] "Sip it again." Joshua puts down his glass, watching Elliot intently. He slowly lifts the glass to his lips again, sipping slowly. "Better?" asks Joshua. Elliot considers for a moment. "Better," he says. "You don't like it?" Joshua puts down his glass, watching Elliot intently. He slowly lifts the glass to his lips again, sipping slowly. Elliot considers for a moment. "It could... grow on me." The slow music and the flowing wine and the vista all swirled into a warmth that they each began to feel somewhere between them, a gravitational well neither could escape. It was an evening without morning in a place without time. Neither could say how much time had passed before Elliot asked Joshua to dance. "Dance?" Joshua recoiled at the question. "I don't know how. I'm sorry." "I haven't the faintest idea how to drink wine, but I suffered through that fortune of a glass, and now I feel giddy enough to ask you to dance. Which is a surprise, even for me. The opportunity may not come again in a melenia. So, I ask again: will you dance with me?" Joshua closes his eyes. "How can I say no?" He smiles, opening them, and stands. Elliot gently reaches out to his fingers, pulling him close. Joshua's back straightens as Elliot stretches his hand around him, letting it rest at the small of his back. The other hand rests loosely to their side. Joshua's spare hand ambles from back to hip and comes to rest up on Elliot's shoulder. "See, not too scary, is it?" [[We haven't started moving yet.]] [[I'm already petrified.]] "We haven't started moving yet." "I'm already petrified." The movement begins with a jolt but immediately falls into a rhythm, as Elliot leads Josh back and forth in tune with the music. [[This isn't so bad.]] [[I'm so bad at this.]] "This isn't so bad." It would be impossible for either of the two boys to say how long they were in that room together. Had either of them asked CINDI, she would tell them it was about four hours and thirty seven minutes, but neither ever did. "I wish this room could be forever." It was a whisper in Josh's ear. [[Maybe it can.]] [[Not this room, but somewhere could be.]] "Maybe it can." Josh stares out to Saturn's rings as his chin rests on Elliot's shoulder. "Not this room, but somewhere could be." Josh stares out to Saturn's rings as his chin rests on Elliot's shoulder. "Would you go? To Proxima b, if we ever find a way to get there?" [[ "Would you go? To Proxima b, if there was a ship?" The socks stick to the ground as he begins to float upwards. "I like this better. Dance (or not?) Then talk about wanting to run away, hint towards that. End with some cute shit. "Don't want to be stuck in cryo next to me for a dozen years?"Christmas on mars Amarizio / Ana dynamic Joana very young, you're not born (Ana is pregnant?) Whose there? Joana, Ana, Issac, Amarizio It was the first thing Joana could remember. Laughter, at wildly varying pitches. The strange hum of low, warm light. Coming from what were usually emergency lights, some red and others yellow, hooked onto the weak stringy leaves of a tomato plant. Bulbous fruits hanging down. Packages underneath. A strange welling up of excitement in her stomach. It's Christmas, and she's never seen her uncle smile so much, mother laugh so much, father eat so much. "An old man would like his time to speak!" Uncle Amarizio bangs together a hard plastic cup and spoon to get everyone's attention. Ana Dandara points out he's not that old. There's laughter. "In that case, this middle-aged man, with wisdom beyond his years, would like to speak." Joana wants to be part of the laughter too. Use the words she's just now beginning to grapple with. [[You're old, Uncle! Don't listen to Mom.]] [[ Joana sees her Mom and Uncle walk out to the clearing, and she follows. Light cascades down from a hole far above them, covered by class. She sees dust being blown across it. "Zio, she didn't send us here just to come back." Joana would come to recognize this exasperated tone in her mother's voice, often directed at her, or later at you. Before you both left. "Earth is my home. Even as its dying... I feel the need to come back." That burning sincerity in Amarizio's voice, that sound still plays in Joana's mind when she is unsure of what step to take next. "It's not right, us being here. As one half of the world burns, the other freezes. I think about Bahia, buried in snow. Our home." "It's not my home." This is sharper. "Zio--" "That's not my name," he snaps. "That's my name for people who don't want to use my name." "-- I left Earth before I could do algebra. You had a childhood there, before it all changed. I didn't. There's nothing for me to go back to. And there's nothing for you to go back to." "There won't be if you and Issac follow ProXima to the end of the galaxy. But if you talked to him, convinced him to--" "Throwing money at a dead planet won't save it. No research can change the inevitable. Plus, we're spending more on the climate control technology than even on the Saturn project. This is--" "It's fucked. And you know it." Joana had only heard that word once before, but knows its bad. "Whose Issac to decide... any of this?" "You know it's not what he wants. His mother--" "-- is dead. And he has the company she forged out of her billions. I don't care what he wants. There's too much at stake for that to matter." They've stopped fidgeting the way they always do, Amarizio opening and closing his fists, Ana Dandara pacing. Now they stood still, staring at one another. "He's my husband. I only care about we want." "So. Let the old world burn, so you can gallivant through the stars, is that it?" "The old world is what we carry with us. Forward." Mom had a fire that could come out, too. But it was different, hers more urgent. "Our job is to find a place for as many of us as we can to land. Earth only has to last long enough for us to leave it." "Please don't tell me you think you're saving the human race, by falling in love with the richest CEO humankind has ever known, and setting up resorts from Venus to Saturn." "It's Christmas, Amarizio. If someone ever did once die on a cross for our sins, then find it in yourself to forgive me for finding the happiness you never could. But pretending to be a bitter old man "This family gives me all the love and joy I need. I'm sorry you can't see that. I'm sorry you always have felt a need for a purpose greater than that, than protecting what we already have. "What are you doing here, Jo?" Mom kneels down to hold your hand. Something w joshua?Backstory Figure out how this happensThere's an uncomfortable silence when you approach your father's workplace. Before you enter, you hesitate. [[Knock.]] [[Ask if he's there.]] [[Go in.]] You knock. The silence remains. / Again, silence. [[Ask if he's there.]] [[Go in.]] "Dad?" you call out. "Are you in there?" The silence remains. / Again, silence. [[Ask CINDI for Issac's location.]] [[Go in.]] "CINDI, where is the location of Issac Alexander?" The voice responds, from a wall panel. "Issac Alexander is on Cassini Station*, in his laboratory. He is X meters in front of you." You walk through the door, and it slides upwards, letting you into the lab. You've been here many times before, but never like this. The central table is occupied by a massive device. You count at least six power sources connected to it by frayed wiring. Several beakers have been inserted to one side of it, and several others lie broken, oozing liquid dripping from the device, to the table, and painfully slowly to the floor. You watch, as one droplet garners enough force from the moon's gravity to break from the static connection with the table. It moves in a straight line, down. But it takes its time. For a coloniazable body, Enceladus is fairly low in mass, and thus gravitational pool. A droplet of primordial ooze, even compared to that, is nothing at all. The drop did not fall quickly. Instead, it lingered, like a tear that cannot be wiped away, and fell, as you noticed the rest of the scene. These broken beakers littered the room, the ooze decorating much of the surfaces. Something happened, that was clear. But now, all was silence. You almost didn't notice the back of your father's head as he sat in a chair, without moving a muscle. Barely breathing. [[Walk around to see his front.]] [[Ask him what's going on.]] [[Grab his shoulder.]] You walk around the lab, so you can see what he looks like from the front. His eyes hang open loosely, darting from one place to the next, and his mouth is slightly ajar. "What... is all this?" you ask on deaf ears. He doesn't even twitch. You reach out, and touch your father's shoulders. It's cold as burning ice, and you pull back your finger immediately. The sting echos on your fingertips for some time. (after 2 of the above:) This has never happened before. Father was always moving, speaking, thinking. This silence and stillness didn't look like death, it was something worse. [[Call for help.]] [[Sit with him.]] "CINDI, get help," you say. "Certainly. I will alert the station's emergency medical staff immediately. And send a message to your mother." [[Thank you.]] [[Don't message her.]] "Thank you." The silence returns. You find a place to sit. "Don't message her," you say. "Not yet." You wonder where she is, what she's doing. How long it would take her to spring into action and find you both, here. "Very well. I will not bother her." You find a place to sit. You pull a clean chair out from under a lab table, place it across from Issac, and sit. His eyes keep darting in silence, zooming across the room. Their light blue almost seemed to glow in the low light of the lab. You try and catch the eyes as they move about the room, crossing your path occasionally. They begin to move slower, each time. Coming back to move past you. Issac's lower lip begins to tremble. [[I'm here, dad.]] [[Say nothing.]] "I'm here, dad." His eyes slow to a stop. Resting when their pointed towards you. You say nothing, keeping your eyes locked towards your father. His eyes slow to a stop. Resting when their pointed towards you. He blinks. Once. Then again, a few times, rapidly. He closes his mouth, and turns. He sees the laboratory in disarray, the flasks broken, sample materials everywhere. Tears stream down his face. The water trickles with minimal sounds, as he contains his whimpering. [[What's wrong?]] [[You need help.]] "What's wrong?" He looks back at you. Locking his eyes onto yours, as if only now he noticed you were actually there. "Of course everything's wrong," he says, as if this were obvious. "That's not the question. The question is what's right." [[What's right, then?]] [[You're not making any sense.]] "What's right, then?" "Nothing. Right now I think the only thing that's right is nothing." His eyes dart up, look from side to side. "I'm sorry, it's hard to hear with all the noise." "You need help." He looks back at you. Locking his eyes onto yours, as if only now he noticed you were actually there. "Of course I need help," he says as if this were obvious. "All of us need help. We forget that. It leads us away from the best path." [[What is the best path?]] [[You're not making any sense.]] "What is this?" "Nothing. Right now I think the best path is nothing." His eyes dart up, look from side to side. "I'm sorry, it's hard to hear with all the noise." "You're not making any sense." "I don't thing I ever made sense. I don't think sense is what I'm trying to make." His eyes dart up, look from side to side. "I'm sorry, it's hard to hear with all the noise." You listen, for a moment. There's not a sound. [[There's no noise.]] [[It's okay, you're hearing me fine.]] "There's no noise." "You, can't hear it, can you? That's... okay. That's fine. But I do need you to listen to me." "It's okay, you're hearing me fine." "Okay. But are you hearing me? I need you to. I need you to listen to me." [[I'm listening.]] [[I'm scared.]] "I'm listening." "Good. It's... like squeezing something flat. For them. That's why we have to stop. Why we can't ever, ever use it. I can't-- it hurt, to hear all this. To feel all this. I don't want to hurt you." "I'm scared." "You have every right to be. It is scary. For them as much as for us. More for them, I think. It's... like squeezing something flat. For them. That's why we have to stop. Why we can't ever, ever use it. I can't-- it hurt, to hear all this. To feel all this. I don't want to hurt you." [[You're not going to hurt me.]] [[Then don't.]] "You're not going to hurt me." "I won't. But I could." He looks down. "Blinding. It's all so blinding. They give hands to build, don't tell you they're fists. Give you machines, don't tell you they're slaves. Give you... toys, don't tell you they're..." "Then don't." "I will. But only because I can't stop it." He looks down. "Blinding. It's all so blinding. They give hands to build, don't tell you they're fists. Give you machines, don't tell you they're slaves. Give you... toys, don't tell you they're..." It's as if he hit a snag in his thoughts. "Is anyone coming? Anyone else?" Now, panic in his eyes. Wider than you'd ever seen them. [[Yes.]] [[No.]] "Yes." "Then I'll speak quickly." Eyes narrow, head hunches. "The fuel. It can hurt." He gives a small nod. "It can hurt." "No." "Good. Good." Eyes soften, head lifts. "This device, that I've been working on... there's something you need to know about it. I can't... exactly explain it, but I know, very deeply, it is true. The fuel, it--" (if no one is coming) Issac seems to be at a loss for words. [[It's okay, take your time.]] [[What about the fuel?]] [[I'm calling for help. You're sick.]] "It's okay, take your time." "Thank you." He takes a breath. "The fuel. The microbes. They feel pain. They hurt. And they-- there's so much more than that. We cannot use them like this. I know we cannot. There is no reason to justify the use of what I have created." "What about the fuel?" "The fuel. The microbes. They feel pain. They hurt. And they-- there's so much more than that. We cannot use them like this. I know we cannot. There is no reason to justify the use of what I have created." [[We have to use them.]] [[I'm calling for help. You're sick.]] [[I don't understand, but I'm trying to.]] "We have to use them." Issac's eyes grow smaller. "There's too much at stake, and you don't know what you're saying." "I know exactly what I am saying. This is life, and this device squashes it." [[They are bacteria. It isn't the same.]] [[How do you know all of this? Why now?]] [[I don't understand, but I'm trying to.]] "They are bacteria. It isn't the same." "If there are gods, wouldn't they say the same as us?" "How do you know all this? Why now?" "There's... something in my head. Not something. Pieces of the microorganism. Whatever was... left. You turn to see Ana Dandara with two members of station security, and medical personnel. She immediately turns her attention to the broken test tubes and material spread throughout the room. "This laboratory is under a high-security lockdown until further notice," she says to the security officers. "Everyone who has made contact with the environment must be quarantined." The medical professionals pull up masks and move towards Issac. His eyes scream fear. "I just need to speak. I don't need quarantine." As he is pulled up by his arms, it looks as if every joint in his body is breaking out of a stiff, frozen sleep. "Let me finish talking to my son. Let me talk to my wife." "We need to get you help, before anything else. We can talk soon." Ana keeps her distance, still under the door's threshold. They take Issac out of the room. He attempts to struggle, but his body is moving too slowly, too haphazardly to be effective. Even so, one of the doctors injects him with something that turns his body limp. He's placed on a stretcher in the hallway. Ana looks at him, lying there, and then turns to you. "Did you touch anything?" [[Yes.]] [[No.]] [[I can't remember.]] "Yes." Known to help patients with really bad PTSD, stuff like that. People who have shit they want to forget. For us, it's simple. All that needs to be tweaked is any memories that indicate the microbes have any degree of intelligence, and anything with Issac in his later stages." Ana notices that amid the hand gestures he uses to explain the concept, his fingers are shaking slightly. "CINDI's already scanning through the crew's memory systems to pinpoint those moments. That data is sent to a neurologist, who identifies the neurons that need to be altered. And, when everyone's in cryo, a special addition to the sleepers takes care of the rest." He looks at the telescope, starts idly fiddling with it. The optical tube squeaking as its moved back and forth. "Oh, and then CINDI deletes any record of having done it at all. Good as new. Our colonists arrive with no qualms about the samples they're collecting and the mission goes forth as planned." The squeaking stops as Ezra picks up his drink, letting the telescope rest. Ana Dandara cradled you, standing by a large window pane aboard the Cronus. All the travelers had boarded the ship, each saying their goodbyes before two years of sleep. Mars sat what looked like above them, the red rock that had been their home. Ana couldn't even see the colony from here. The planet looked the same as it had in those first images taken from flyby probes a century ago: naked and new, dead and timeless. Sitting amongst a profound silence. Ana Dandara thought of the miracle of your birth, how this place would hold the markers of that profound joy. Thought of how once the doctors were done with you, she cradled you not to differently to how she did now, but for the first time, thought of how she was one of the first mothers to hold a Martian in her arms. Issac stood behind, preparing their sleepers for their trip. Ana asked him, without turning, "Do you think he'll/she'll/they'll remember?" "Remember what?" asked Issac, not turning his head. "Anything of this place," she replied. "Those barren rocks contain so much of me." "We can hope," Issac turned. "Sometimes, I try to reach back and gather images from Earth. Not the ones from films or images, but my own. But I only come up with... snippets, single frames of memory. I'm not even sure they're real." Issac walked to join you at the window. "What do you remember?" Ana looked down into your eyes as they shifted from her face to the window to the corners of the room. This was the first time you experienced weightlessness. Your parents had prepared a sedative for what they thought would be inevitable tears. But, they never came. [[I can't remember anything.]] [[An ocean.]] [[A forest.]] [[Snow.]] "I can't remember... anything." She spoke with a softness. You squirmed in her arms, confused. She never could imagine the stories her mother used to tell about Earth. She would always tell Ana about the inn she ran by a beach on the coast of Brazil. Ana thought about the stories her mother didn't tell, about what happened when the seas began to rise. About what they had to do to get on the ship to Mars. The stories she never had to tell, that Ana found as shards in offhand phrases and empty stares. Issac turned back from the sleepers, looking past Ana and to the window. "That's Earth, isn't it?" "Where?" Ana looked out, for a dot a bit more blue than the rest, but found nothing. But Issac was the stargazer, not her. "I remember... an ocean. Sand between my toes and my skin soaking in the sun..." Ana thought about the stories her mother to tell, about the inn she ran by a beach on the coast of Brazil. Ana thought about the stories her mother didn't tell, about what happened when the seas began to rise. About what they had to do to get on the ship to Mars. The stories she never had to tell, that Ana found as shards in offhand phrases and empty stares. But the only memory she had was of the sand and warmth, and the rhythmic water flowing in and out in waves. "That ocean's out there, somewhere." Issac turned back from the sleepers, looking past Ana and to the window. "That's Earth, isn't it?" "Where?" Ana looked out, for a dot a bit more blue than the rest, but found nothing. But Issac was the stargazer, not her. "I remember... a forest. The tall stalks of trees, the light speckling the floor." Ana remembered being scared, lost. Once, she asked her mother about the time she got lost in the forest, but she didn't remember. Instead, she'd tell Ana about the inn she ran by a beach on the coast of Brazil, admist those same trees. Ana thought about the stories her mother didn't tell, about what happened when the seas began to rise. About what they had to do to get on the ship to Mars. The stories she never had to tell, that Ana found as shards in offhand phrases and empty stares. But the only memory she had was that afternoon, lost amongst the trees and brush. "Those trees are still there, somewhere." Issac turned back from the sleepers, looking past Ana and to the window. "That's Earth, isn't it?" "Where?" Ana looked out, for a dot a bit more blue than the rest, but found nothing. But Issac was the stargazer, not her. "I remember... snow. How fierce my mother held my hand as she looked up and we watched. I thought the stars were falling out of the sky." Ana remembered how her bones felt frozen as the chill settled in. She never asked her mother about that moment, the beginning of the end. Instead, Ana just listened as she'd tell her about the inn she ran by a beach on the coast of Brazil, admist those same trees. Ana thought about the stories her mother didn't tell, about what happened when the seas began to rise. About what they had to do to get on the ship to Mars. The stories she never had to tell, that Ana found as shards in offhand phrases and empty stares. But the only memory she had was of those snowflakes flickering down towards the Earth, too soft to be menacing. "It's snowing out there, somewhere, I'm sure." Issac turned back from the sleepers, looking past Ana and to the window. "That's Earth, isn't it?" "Where?" Ana looked out, for a dot a bit more blue than the rest, but found nothing. But Issac was the stargazer, not her. He came to the window, putting his arm around Ana and pointed. "There, I think. We should make sure the little one gets a good look." Ana lifted you up a bit higher, bringing you to the window. Your eyes were wide. [[That's our home. We'll be back, some day.]] [[That's the world we're leaving behind.]] [[That's where your mom was born.]] "That's our home." Ana looked into your eyes, the stars reflected back. "We'll be back, some day." "Earth, the one and only," added Issac with a strained smile. You gnawed at one of your fingers. Ana gave you a kiss, and whispered in your ear. "That's the world we're leaving behind." Ana looked into your eyes, the stars reflected back. "Earth, the one and only," added Issac with a strained smile. You gnawed at one of your fingers. Ana gave you a kiss, and whispered in your ear. "That's where your mom was born." Ana looked into your eyes, the stars reflected back. "And dad," Issac added with a smile. [[Don't forget it.]] [[Don't look back.]] "Don't forget it." The sounds seeped into your mind, even though you didn't quite know the words. "Don't look back." The sounds seeped into your mind, even though you didn't quite know the words. Issac wrapped his arms around you and your mother as the three of you absorbed the last images of the Martian surface. The last glimpses of that bluish dot, getting lost within the stars. "Ana, it's time." [[I know.]] [[Just a minute more.]] "I know," she said. Issac's arms melted down as the moment melted too, and all that was left were the last minute safety checks and entering the cryogenic sleeping chambers and then two years of dreamless sleep. "Just a minute more." The moment lingered. Ana held you as Issac held you both and even in the mechanical cold of the machine the three of you were contained in, there was warmth. Then, Issac's arms melted down as the moment melted too, and all that was left were the last minute safety checks and entering the cryogenic sleeping chambers and then two years of dreamless sleep.Def: Memories of interacting w ppl before trip Maybe: Collecting first sample Locations: "Swimming pool" around orbital station Other place from ch6
